update.description:
Ran into a bug in the version of tinyxml2 that is released in ubuntu. Large log files, specifically large blocks of CDATA cause tinyxml2 to fail.

Fortunately version 3 of tinyxml2 works. 

This pull request changes gazebo to rely solely on the internal version of tinyxml2. I also removed public facing inclusion of tinyxml2 in LogPlay.

@\_jrivero\_ , do you think this will negatively affect anything?

I can't write a test for this because the test requires a very large log file, and we shouldn't include such a file in the gazebo sources. I have a 14GB log file on my PC that anyone can have for testing. 

[Jenkins](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2146)
update.title: Internal tinyxml2

content.raw:
Added in 79d7810 (branch `internal_tinyxml2_scpeters`).

That branch also has a reduction in ifdef's since I believe they aren't necessary since the code where it's used is already in the gazebo namespace, so `tinyxml2::` should resolve properly in either case.
content.html:
Added in 79d7810 (branch internal_tinyxml2_scpeters).

That branch also has a reduction in ifdef's since I believe they aren't necessary since the code where it's used is already in the gazebo namespace, so tinyxml2:: should resolve properly in either case.

content.raw: Ok, I think this `namespace` hack isn't necessary, but I also think we don't need any of the `ifdef`s in this file, since we have `using namespace gazebo;`
content.html: Ok, I think this namespace hack isn't necessary, but I also think we don't need any of the ifdefs in this file, since we have using namespace gazebo;

content.raw:
Instead of manually specifying `USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2`, what if we just search for an external package with version 3 or greater and fall back to the internal copy if that can't be found? Homebrew and Xenial already have the proper versions.

~~~
diff -r 2c371f198820 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Wed Mar 23 10:09:11 2016 -0700
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Thu Mar 24 14:58:06 2016 -0700
@@ -209,8 +209,14 @@
 
   # Use system installation on UNIX and Apple, and internal copy on Windows
   if (UNIX OR APPLE)
-    message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
-    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2_VERSION_3 tinyxml2>=3)
+    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 True)
+    if (TINYXML2_VERSION_3_FOUND)
+      message (STATUS "Using system tinyxml2.")
+    else()
+      message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
+      set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    endif()
   elseif(WIN32)
     message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
     set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
~~~
content.html:
Instead of manually specifying USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2, what if we just search for an external package with version 3 or greater and fall back to the internal copy if that can't be found? Homebrew and Xenial already have the proper versions.

diff -r 2c371f198820 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake    Wed Mar 23 10:09:11 2016 -0700
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake    Thu Mar 24 14:58:06 2016 -0700
@@ -209,8 +209,14 @@

   # Use system installation on UNIX and Apple, and internal copy on Windows
   if (UNIX OR APPLE)
-    message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
-    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    pkg_check_modules(TINYXML2_VERSION_3 tinyxml2>=3)
+    set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 True)
+    if (TINYXML2_VERSION_3_FOUND)
+      message (STATUS "Using system tinyxml2.")
+    else()
+      message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
+      set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)
+    endif()
   elseif(WIN32)
     message (STATUS "Using internal tinyxml2.")
     set (USE_EXTERNAL_TINYXML2 False)

content.raw: It's a good idea. But, I think we'd run into a problem when you have the external version of tinyxml2 installed, but still want to use the internal version when compiling gazebo.
content.html: It's a good idea. But, I think we'd run into a problem when you have the external version of tinyxml2 installed, but still want to use the internal version when compiling gazebo.

weird hack idea:

namespace gazebo
{
#include <tinyxml2.h>
}

would this let us skip a bunch of ifdefs?

content.raw: I agree with not taking the rules as a solid rock. The alternative is the same for the rest of problems we found in all our dependencies: report upstream and help with the fix and patches. We have started this way, so I'm fine with workarounds until the fix arrives. Once the fix is ready, Debian/Ubuntu maintainers/developers usually backport it to current Ubuntu/Debian versions since it fixes a critical problem.
content.html: I agree with not taking the rules as a solid rock. The alternative is the same for the rest of problems we found in all our dependencies: report upstream and help with the fix and patches. We have started this way, so I'm fine with workarounds until the fix arrives. Once the fix is ready, Debian/Ubuntu maintainers/developers usually backport it to current Ubuntu/Debian versions since it fixes a critical problem.

content.raw:
Right, we would be tricking the rules. I'm mostly playing devils advocate here, I get the rules but the rules seem broken. In this case we have a bug in upstream code. New code of the upstream package works, but the OS is not using for the new code for the foreseeable future. It's also unclear whether a fix can be propagated to earlier versions.

The result is the our program is now broken. According to the rules we'll have to live with broken code, and there is nothing to do except rewrite all the code that we depend upon and call it something different. They is *very* broken. 

Unless there is an alternative, I will will take the rule-bending approach because a non-broken Gazebo is worth far more than strict adherence to the rules.
content.html:
Right, we would be tricking the rules. I'm mostly playing devils advocate here, I get the rules but the rules seem broken. In this case we have a bug in upstream code. New code of the upstream package works, but the OS is not using for the new code for the foreseeable future. It's also unclear whether a fix can be propagated to earlier versions.

The result is the our program is now broken. According to the rules we'll have to live with broken code, and there is nothing to do except rewrite all the code that we depend upon and call it something different. They is very broken.

Unless there is an alternative, I will will take the rule-bending approach because a non-broken Gazebo is worth far more than strict adherence to the rules.

content.raw: It sounds to me like we would be tricking the rules but yes, if you made your own fork of tinyxml with no external exposure, that can pass the debian policy although we could be going against the spirit of these rules.
content.html: It sounds to me like we would be tricking the rules but yes, if you made your own fork of tinyxml with no external exposure, that can pass the debian policy although we could be going against the spirit of these rules.

content.raw: It sounds like I could copy tinyxml2, rename it to something else (natexml for demo sake), use it directly in Gazebo, and debian will have no issue because there is no system install of "natexml".
content.html: It sounds like I could copy tinyxml2, rename it to something else (natexml for demo sake), use it directly in Gazebo, and debian will have no issue because there is no system install of "natexml".

content.raw:
Thanks for the clarification. 

I just want to make sure the policy you are referring to actually applies here. With this pull request, we are directly compiling into libgazebo_util.so a version of tinyxml2 that has a different namespace from tinyxml2. No headers related to tinyxml2 are installed, and no public facing api uses tinyxml2. Any person can use gazebo with the system install of tinyxml2 without experiencing any problems.

If this policy still holds, I'm inclined to write my own xml parser and ditch tinyxml2. I'd rather re-invent the wheel that have a persistent bug in Gazebo.
content.html:
Thanks for the clarification.

I just want to make sure the policy you are referring to actually applies here. With this pull request, we are directly compiling into libgazebo_util.so a version of tinyxml2 that has a different namespace from tinyxml2. No headers related to tinyxml2 are installed, and no public facing api uses tinyxml2. Any person can use gazebo with the system install of tinyxml2 without experiencing any problems.

If this policy still holds, I'm inclined to write my own xml parser and ditch tinyxml2. I'd rather re-invent the wheel that have a persistent bug in Gazebo.

content.raw:
Here is a script that will reproduce the problem:

```
#!ruby


#!/usr/bin/env ruby

f = File.open("test.log", "w")

f.write("<test><![CDATA[")
for i in 0..100000
  for i in 0..1000
    f.write('00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000')
  end
end
f.write("]]></test>")

f.close()
```

When you playback the log file with tinyxml2 version 2.2, you'll get the following error:


```
#!c++

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:119] Unable to load file[test.log]. Check the Gazebo server log file for more information.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:127] EXCEPTION: Error parsing log file


```

When you playback the logfile with tinyxml2 version 3.0, you'll get:


```
#!c++

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:150] EXCEPTION: Log file is missing the <gazebo_log> element

```

I've included this script the the tinyxml2 issue tracker.
content.html:
Here is a script that will reproduce the problem:

#!/usr/bin/env ruby

f = File.open("test.log", "w")

f.write("<test><![CDATA[")
for i in 0..100000
  for i in 0..1000
    f.write('00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000')
  end
end
f.write("]]></test>")

f.close()

When you playback the log file with tinyxml2 version 2.2, you'll get the following error:

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:119] Unable to load file[test.log]. Check the Gazebo server log file for more information.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:127] EXCEPTION: Error parsing log file

When you playback the logfile with tinyxml2 version 3.0, you'll get:

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:150] EXCEPTION: Log file is missing the <gazebo_log> element

I've included this script the the tinyxml2 issue tracker.

content.raw:
Sorry, we probably are calling "debian version" to different things:

 * Packages .deb from osrfoundation repository will be built using the default, so the internal copy after this PR. We can do anything we want with our own packages.
 * Same for the source builds.
 * Packages directly from debian/ubuntu repositories can not use an embedded version of tinyxml (by policy), so they won't be build using our internal copy.

In the case of we have potential users hit by that bug, the workaround would be to use osrfoundation.org .deb repository.
content.html:
Sorry, we probably are calling "debian version" to different things:

  • Packages .deb from osrfoundation repository will be built using the default, so the internal copy after this PR. We can do anything we want with our own packages.
  • Same for the source builds.
  • Packages directly from debian/ubuntu repositories can not use an embedded version of tinyxml (by policy), so they won't be build using our internal copy.

In the case of we have potential users hit by that bug, the workaround would be to use osrfoundation.org .deb repository.

content.raw: That means anyone using the debian version of gazebo will experience the error in tinyxml2, right?

content.raw: I've made the change in debian repository to use the system version there. Our release repositories for gazebo7 and gazebo8 will fall to the default value, no code added there. I've added some documentation about the option of using tinyxml versions and update the Changelog according to these changes. In the branch `internal_tinyxml2_jrivero`.
